text: [Music]
hello my name is Ven and I'm sitting
here at go to Berlin uh with
am he is a post at the Technical
University of Munich and also the
co-founder of a company called cqs in
Munich welcome Emma hi Sven thanks for
having me uh Emma um who are you and
what are you doing quality I earn my
living doing software quality analysis
in two roles on the one hand I'm a
researcher and in that role I'm
interested in which important
characteristics of software like quality
can analyses tell us about and in my
second role as a consultant I care about
what is actually useful because there's
many things that are easy to measure but
not relevant to know okay and your talk
at go to Berlin was about a subset of
your research and work in practice uh
what is it about my talk is about how to
debug software development teams by
looking at repository data by that I
mean we always have two architectures we
have a technical architecture how a
system is decomposed into subsystems and
how they communicate and we have an
organizational architecture like how a
team is decomposed into sub teams and if
those two don't match problems arise and
in my talk I present analyses that show
us where mismatches happen and what the
consequences are typically in form of
problems in the code a typical mismatch
is if two different sub teams need to
collaborate but can't really then a
typical workaround is that one team
copies code from the other team and not
just a bit of code but often like tens
or hundreds of thousands of lines of
code and then this code base is
duplicated and needs to be maintained in
two places and what we then see is that
buck fixes only happen in one area and
not in the other and you have all the
problems that you have if you have a
duplicated code base and the underlying
root cause is that the teams can't
really communicate in the way they would
like to do on their code okay and um how
do customers uh react to these findings
um this typically depends a bit
typically they glad to know it but they
cannot always rectify the root cause
sometimes it was a deliberate choice to
duplicate the code base to stick with
that example and sometimes they can't
really change the fact that the team in
this setting cannot work well together
but then they need to take measures to
alleviate the problem like for example
use a clone management tool to at least
fix the bugs in all the places where
they have been copied to okay but in
your work you also show a path to
Improvement so yes we do but typically
there's more or less thorough and more
or less painful Solutions and it always
depends on the context how radical a
change you can or want to do so
typically those analyses point out
problems but you require context
information to decide which solution is
the best one and this is beyond what the
tool can do this is where you experience
an interpreting the results and in
knowing the context comes in do you
maintain a single database with all your
analytical
findings yes we have an index in our
tool where we integrate all the data we
use to run our analyses on but it
typically stems from different sources
like from Version Control Systems from
Buck tracker from tracers from Pro
profile as we run in production systems
depends a bit on the analysis question
and it also depends on the development
and production platform but you collect
all the data also from many different
companies then yes what is in your
opinion a very interesting or very funny
finding you have across all the the
companies I think what what surprised me
the most is that typically when we first
speak with companies they all say that
they are special cuz they develop under
time pressure and under lot of stress
which is really the unifying thing
between our different customers and like
at first glance an embedded system which
you write in C looks very different from
a host system written Cobalt or an ABAB
system uh which runs on sap but if you
take a step back the problems you have
if you have to maintain those systems
for 10 years or 20 are very similar you
always have teams you always have
architectures and they need to match or
otherwise you have to fix the problems
that arise when you maintain that
software how did you decide to work on
this specific problem or on these
problems good good question let me think
um I think because these were the
problems our customers made us work on
when we did our PhD thesis on program
analysis we typically like looking back
worked on problems that were interesting
from a scientific B point of view for
example because they used a very
complicated algorithm but since we
founded the company we were forced to
Look a Lot into problems that are
relevant
much more than how sexy they are from a
scientific standpoint and so we looked
into these problems because our
customers um suffered from them what are
future research directions in terms of
program
analysis I think like the most important
research direction is to reduce the
feedback time many of the analysis tools
run in a nightly build and then you have
to wait until next day to get your
results and this is this takes too long
especially if you run in in a
multibranch development where not even
every single Branch the analyses are
performed and a lot of the research work
we've been doing is on incremental
analysis algorithms so that you get your
feedback after one second and not in the
next day and on multibranch analyses so
that we analyze all the branches
concurrently with the incremental
analysis algorithms so that you get
immediate feedback which is relevant to
your work and not late feedback the next
day for the enti team okay so basically
it would mean that we could embed these
tools in our IDE and get basically
instant uh uh feedback yes sir okay
thanks for doing the interview with
us thanks for having me
